<!-- Title: Start --> <style> @import url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Roboto:wght@400;700&display=swap'); body { margin: 0; font-family: 'Roboto', sans-serif; } .welcome-background { background: linear-gradient(rgba(0,0,0,0.6), rgba(0,0,0,0.6)), url('https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1550745165-9bc0b252726f?ixlib=rb-1.2.1&auto=format&fit=crop&w=2250&q=80') no-repeat center center/cover; min-height: 100vh; padding: 50px 20px; display: flex; flex-direction: column; justify-content: center; align-items: center; text-align: center; color: white; } .content-box { background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.45); padding: 40px; border-radius: 20px; max-width: 900px; box-shadow: 0 0 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.6); animation: fadeIn 1.5s ease-in-out; } @keyframes fadeIn { from { opacity: 0; transform: scale(0.95); } to { opacity: 1; transform: scale(1); } } h1 { font-size: 42px; margin-bottom: 20px; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #00d2ff, #3a7bd5); -webkit-background-clip: text; -webkit-text-fill-color: transparent; } h2 { font-size: 28px; color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 30px; } .content-box p { font-size: 18px; color: #e0e0e0; margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; } .start-button { display: inline-block; padding: 12px 28px; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #00d2ff, #3a7bd5); color: white; text-decoration: none; border-radius: 30px; font-weight: bold; transition: 0.3s; font-size: 18px; margin-top: 30px; } .start-button:hover { background: linear-gradient(90deg, #3a7bd5, #00d2ff); transform: scale(1.05); box-shadow: 0 0 12px #00d2ff; } .footer { margin-top: 50px; font-size: 14px; color: #cccccc; border-top: 1px solid #555; padding-top: 20px; } </style> <div class="welcome-background"> <div class="content-box"> <h1>Hidden Figures: The Story of Ava Goldberg</h1> <h2>An Interactive Journey Through Computing’s Untold Past</h2> <p><strong>Step into the world of Ava Goldberg, a fictional ENIAC programmer inspired by the real women who shaped the dawn of computing.</strong></p> <p>In a time when computers filled entire rooms and women’s work was often invisible, Ava faces tough choices: Will she claim her place in history, or let her story be forgotten? Can she build a legacy for future generations, or will the barriers of her era prove too great?</p> <p>This interactive story lets you guide Ava through moments of challenge, courage, and discovery. Your decisions will shape her path-navigating gender bias, forging alliances, mentoring others, and deciding how (or if) her story is preserved.</p> <p><em>Inspired by real events and research from our Digital Cultures course, Ava’s journey explores themes of gender, labor, recognition, and the power of storytelling in technology.</em></p> <p><strong>How to play:</strong></p> <ul style="text-align:left; display:inline-block; color:#e0e0e0; font-size:17px; line-height:1.7; margin:10px auto 18px auto;"> <li>Read each scene and consider the choices presented to you.</li> <li>Click on your chosen path to see where it leads Ava next.</li> <li>Look for real historical facts and context in the “Did you know?” boxes.</li> <li>You can replay and choose different paths to explore alternate outcomes.</li> </ul> <p style="margin-top:10px;"><strong>Ready to begin?</strong> Click below to start Ava’s story.</p> <a class="start-button">[[Meet Ava Goldberg->Ava Intro]]</a> <div class="footer"> <p>This interactive story is inspired by the lives of the ENIAC women and other hidden figures in STEM, as discussed in Digital Cultures, Spring 2025.</p> <p>Created as an unessay project. All research and historical facts are credited throughout the story.</p> </div> </div> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Intro --> <style> .story-intro { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-intro h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-intro p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } </style> <div class="story-intro"> <h2>Ava Goldberg: ENIAC Programmer, 1945</h2> <p> Ava Goldberg has always been drawn to numbers. Growing up in Philadelphia during the Great Depression, she excelled in mathematics at a time when few girls were encouraged to pursue science. With the outbreak of World War II, her skills became her ticket to a new world: the Ballistic Research Laboratory at the University of Pennsylvania. </p> <p> There, Ava joined a team of bright, ambitious women hired as "computers"—human calculators responsible for the complex equations needed to improve artillery accuracy. When the secret ENIAC project began, Ava was among the select few chosen to program the world’s first electronic computer. She learned to wire panels, read blueprints, and translate mathematical problems into machine instructions, all without a manual or precedent. </p> <p> The lab is a maze of tangled wires, punch cards, and possibility. The work is grueling and the hours long, but Ava finds meaning in the challenge. Still, she can’t ignore the reality: while her calculations shape history, the spotlight rarely shines her way. The men are called "engineers" and "inventors," while the women are labeled "clerical" or "support." </p> <p> Ava dreams of a future where women’s technical brilliance is recognized, not hidden behind closed doors. Each decision she makes—whether to quietly do her job, fight for credit, or band together with her colleagues—could echo through the digital age. The story she helps write may one day be remembered… or forgotten. </p> <a class="start-button">[[Begin Ava's Journey->Ava Scene 1]]</a> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 1 --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>ENIAC Lab, Philadelphia, 1945</h2> <p> The ENIAC lab is alive with energy and tension. Overhead, fluorescent lights flicker against high ceilings. The room hums with the constant whir of cooling fans and the sharp click of relays, while the scent of solder, hot metal, and machine oil lingers in the air. Rows of massive black cabinets—each filled with thousands of vacuum tubes—loom over you and your colleagues. Tangled wires snake across the floor, connecting panels and consoles in a puzzle only a handful of people in the world can decipher. </p> <p> You, Ava Goldberg, are one of six women who have been entrusted with programming this unprecedented machine. The work is grueling: translating complex ballistics equations into logical instructions, physically rewiring circuits, and debugging problems that have no precedent. Some nights, you barely see your rented room before returning to the lab at dawn. </p> <p> Yet, despite your expertise, the men in charge rarely acknowledge your contributions. The engineers and project directors—always addressed as “Doctor” or “Professor”—discuss theory and design, while you and the other women are expected to “make it work.” You know the ENIAC better than anyone, but you’re called a “computer girl,” not a programmer. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> The original ENIAC programmers—Kathleen McNulty Mauchly Antonelli, Jean Jennings Bartik, Frances Elizabeth Holberton, Marlyn Wescoff Meltzer, Frances Bilas Spence, and Ruth Lichterman Teitelbaum—were all women. Hired first as “human computers,” they became the world’s first professional computer programmers, learning to program ENIAC from blueprints and logic alone. Their pioneering work was largely unrecognized for decades.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <p> Today, the project director gathers everyone for an announcement: a high-profile demonstration for military brass and the national press is scheduled. Only the male engineers will present ENIAC’s capabilities. The women are expected to stay in the background, running calculations, fixing bugs, and making sure nothing goes wrong. </p> <p> The air is thick with anticipation—and frustration. You know this is a pivotal moment, not just for the project, but for your own future. Will your work finally be seen, or will history pass you by? </p> <p> <strong>What will you do?</strong> </p> <ul> <li>[[Quietly do your job, hoping your work will speak for itself->Ava Scene 2A]]</li> <li>[[Speak up and ask to be included in the public demo->Ava Scene 2B]]</li> <li>[[Gather the other women to document your work together->Ava Scene 2C]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 2A --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Behind the Scenes</h2> <p> You focus on your work, double-checking every calculation and quietly fixing last-minute glitches as the demonstration approaches. The ENIAC is temperamental—vacuum tubes burn out, punch cards jam, and the wiring maze seems endless. You and the other women crawl inside the machine to swap out components, hands stained with ink and oil. The engineers rely on your steady hands and sharp mind, but when the big day arrives, you’re asked to step aside as the men take center stage. </p> <p> The demonstration is a blur of flashing lights and whirring circuits. From the shadows, you watch as the generals and reporters marvel at ENIAC’s power. You can’t help but feel a surge of pride as the machine performs flawlessly, knowing that every calculation, every connection, was made possible by your unseen labor. </p> <p> Yet as the applause echoes down the hall, you realize your contribution is invisible. The headlines the next day praise the "brilliant engineers"—all men. You return to your workbench, wondering if history will ever remember the hands that brought ENIAC to life, or if your story will be lost in the shadows of the machine. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> The ENIAC programmers not only wrote the first computer programs, but also physically debugged the machine—sometimes crawling inside to replace failed vacuum tubes. Their work was so new that there were no manuals or programming languages; they had to invent every step themselves.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Odetta Blog; Unsung History Podcast; eniacprogrammers.org</span> </div> <p> <strong>What will you do next?</strong> </p> <ul> <li>[[Continue working quietly, hoping things will change over time->Ava Scene 3A]]</li> <li>[[Start keeping a secret journal of your work and experiences->Ava Scene 3B]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 2B --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Speaking Up</h2> <p> After the meeting, you take a deep breath and approach the project director. Your heart pounds as you explain that the demonstration would not be possible without the work of the women programmers. You ask, respectfully but firmly, to be included in the public presentation—not just as support, but as a true contributor to the ENIAC’s success. </p> <p> The director’s expression shifts from surprise to discomfort. He mumbles about “protocol” and “public image,” insisting that the engineers are better suited for the spotlight. You sense the tension in the room as some of your female colleagues glance your way—some with admiration, others with fear. The men avoid your eyes, eager to move on. </p> <p> Word of your boldness spreads quickly. Some women thank you for speaking up, grateful that someone voiced what they all feel. Others warn you to be careful—opportunities for women are rare, and challenging authority can have consequences. Still, you feel a quiet pride for having demanded what you deserve, even if the outcome is uncertain. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Women who advocated for recognition in early computing often faced professional risks, including dismissal or being labeled “troublemakers.” Many remained silent to keep their jobs.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <p> <strong>What will you do next?</strong> </p> <ul> <li>[[Accept the director’s decision and focus on your work->Ava Scene 3A]]</li> <li>[[Organize a meeting with the other women to discuss next steps->Ava Scene 3C]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 2C --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Documenting the Truth</h2> <p> Disappointed by the lack of recognition, you gather the other women in a quiet corner of the lab after hours. The room is filled with a mix of frustration and determination. You propose that you all begin documenting your work—writing detailed notes, saving diagrams, and, when possible, taking photographs of your setups and wiring. </p> <p> The process is both empowering and risky. You share memories of long nights debugging code, the thrill of solving impossible problems, and the sting of being overlooked. Each entry in your collective journal is an act of quiet resistance, a promise to future generations that women were here, and they mattered. </p> <p> As the demonstration approaches, you feel a new sense of solidarity. Even if the world isn’t ready to hear your story, you’re determined to make sure it isn’t lost. Together, you vow to protect your records until the time is right to share them. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Decades later, historians were able to reconstruct the true story of ENIAC thanks to personal notes, photographs, and oral histories preserved by the women who worked on the project.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <p> <strong>What will you do next?</strong> </p> <ul> <li>[[Share your documentation with a trusted journalist->Ava Scene 3D]]</li> <li>[[Hide the records for now, waiting for the right moment->Ava Scene 3E]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 3A --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Invisible, But Essential</h2> <p> You settle into a routine, arriving early and staying late, always making sure ENIAC runs smoothly. New faces join the lab, and you train them patiently—even when they’re promoted above you. The men in charge rarely mention your name, but you know the machine’s secrets better than anyone. </p> <p> Sometimes, you overhear visitors marveling at the “miracle” of ENIAC, never realizing the miracle is the work of women like you. The pride you feel is private, a quiet satisfaction that lingers as you watch the machine’s blinking lights late at night. </p> <p> Years pass. When the war ends, the lab changes. Many women leave, replaced by returning soldiers. You remain, your expertise indispensable yet uncelebrated. The world moves on, and you wonder if anyone will ever know what you accomplished. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> After WWII, many women who had pioneered programming were pushed out of computing jobs as men returned and the field became more prestigious.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <p> <strong>What do you do?</strong> </p> <ul> <li>[[Attend an ENIAC anniversary celebration quietly, content in your private pride->Ava Scene 4C]]</li> <li>[[Write a letter to a journalist about your experience->Ava Scene 4A]]</li> <li>[[Reach out to the other ENIAC women and suggest you write a joint memoir->Ava Scene 4B]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 3B --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>The Secret Journal</h2> <p> Each night, after the lab empties, you take out a small notebook and record the day’s challenges and triumphs. You write about debugging ENIAC’s circuits, the camaraderie with the other women, and the sting of being left out of the spotlight. The journal becomes your confidant—a place where your story is valued, even if only by you. </p> <p> Over time, your notes grow into a detailed chronicle of the ENIAC project. You sketch diagrams, tape in punch card samples, and jot down the tricks you invented to coax the machine into working. The act of writing helps you process both pride and frustration. </p> <p> One evening, you wonder what will become of your journal. Will it gather dust in a drawer, or could it help someone, someday, understand what really happened here? </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Historians later relied on personal notes, letters, and diaries kept by women programmers to reconstruct the hidden history of early computing.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <p> <strong>What do you do?</strong> </p> <ul> <li>[[Share your journal with a trusted historian or journalist->Ava Scene 4D]]</li> <li>[[Keep your journal hidden, unsure if the world is ready for your story->Ava Scene 4E]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 4C --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Private Pride</h2> <p> You attend the ENIAC anniversary celebration quietly, blending into the crowd as the men take the stage. Their speeches are full of technical jargon and grand claims, but you hear echoes of your own work in every story they tell. </p> <p> No one calls your name. You smile politely, feeling a bittersweet pride as you watch the machine you helped build become a legend. The recognition is not yours, but the satisfaction of knowing your own worth remains. </p> <p> After the event, you return home and place your old lab badge in a box of keepsakes. You wonder if anyone will ever find it and ask about the woman behind the number. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women in early tech fields found pride in their private achievements, even when public recognition was denied.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Reflect on your legacy and consider sharing your story someday->Ava Scene 5E]]</li> <li>[[Decide to move on and focus on new challenges->Ava Scene 5F]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 4A --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Breaking the Silence</h2> <p> You decide you can’t let the story of the ENIAC women fade into obscurity. You gather your courage and write a detailed letter to a local journalist, describing your work and the crucial roles played by your colleagues. You include stories of late nights, technical breakthroughs, and the sting of being left out of the spotlight. </p> <p> Days pass before you receive a reply. The journalist is intrigued but skeptical—after all, the official records barely mention you. She asks if you have any documents or proof of your work. </p> <p> You sift through your old notebooks and diagrams, deciding what to share. The decision feels momentous: will your evidence finally bring the truth to light, or will it be ignored like so many times before? </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> It took decades for journalists and historians to uncover the stories of the ENIAC women, often relying on personal archives and oral histories.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Share your personal notes and calculations->Ava Scene 5A]]</li> <li>[[Invite other ENIAC women to share their stories too->Ava Scene 5B]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 4B --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>The Memoir Project</h2> <p> Inspired by solidarity, you propose a joint memoir to the other ENIAC women. Some are hesitant, worried about professional risks or simply too busy with new lives, but a few are eager to join you. Together, you begin drafting chapters, sharing memories, and gathering old notes and photos. </p> <p> The process is slow, but empowering. You reminisce about the challenges you overcame, the creative solutions you invented, and the camaraderie that kept you going. Each story you write down feels like reclaiming a piece of history. </p> <p> As the manuscript takes shape, you debate how to share it with the world. Should you self-publish to ensure your voices are unfiltered, or approach a major publisher for wider reach, risking editorial changes? </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Oral histories, memoirs, and collective storytelling have been crucial for recovering women’s roles in science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Self-publish your memoir to ensure your voices are unfiltered->Ava Scene 5C]]</li> <li>[[Approach a major publisher, risking editorial changes for wider reach->Ava Scene 5D]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5A --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Evidence in Hand</h2> <p> You gather your notes and calculations, carefully organizing them for the journalist. Each page is a testament to nights spent debugging circuits, inventing new programming techniques, and collaborating with your fellow women programmers. </p> <p> When the journalist visits, she pores over your documents with growing excitement. She asks questions about the technical challenges, the teamwork, and the lack of recognition. You answer honestly, feeling a mix of relief and anxiety. </p> <p> The journalist promises to write an article that tells the world about the ENIAC women. As she leaves, you wonder if this will finally be the moment your story is heard. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> The rediscovery of the ENIAC women’s stories often began with personal archives—notes, diagrams, and letters that survived decades of neglect.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Wait for the article to be published->Ava Scene 6A]]</li> <li>[[Contact other women to encourage them to share their stories too->Ava Scene 6B]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5B --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Strength in Numbers</h2> <p> You reach out to your former colleagues, encouraging them to share their stories with the journalist as well. Some are hesitant at first, but your enthusiasm is contagious. Soon, you’re organizing group calls and meetings, each woman adding her voice to the growing chorus. </p> <p> The journalist is thrilled, realizing she has stumbled upon a much bigger story. She records interviews, collects documents, and begins to piece together the true history of the ENIAC project. </p> <p> As you listen to your friends recount their experiences, you feel a deep sense of solidarity. Together, you are rewriting history. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Collective storytelling and group interviews were crucial for reconstructing the full scope of women’s contributions to early computing.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help organize a public panel to share your stories->Ava Scene 6C]]</li> <li>[[Let the journalist handle the story and return to your private life->Ava Scene 6D]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 3C --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Solidarity in the Shadows</h2> <p> You invite the other women programmers to a quiet meeting after hours. The mood is tense at first, but as you share your frustrations and hopes, a sense of camaraderie grows. You realize you are not alone—each of you has felt overlooked and undervalued. </p> <p> Together, you brainstorm ways to support one another. Some suggest documenting your work, others propose pooling resources to advocate for better recognition. The conversation is filled with both laughter and tears, as you recall the obstacles you’ve overcome. </p> <p> By the end of the night, you’ve formed a pact: to stand together, to amplify each other’s voices, and to never let your contributions be erased. The path forward is uncertain, but you feel stronger knowing you have allies by your side. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Women in early computing often formed informal support networks to share knowledge and encouragement, even when formal recognition was denied.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <p> <strong>What do you do?</strong> </p> <ul> <li>[[Begin a collective documentation project with the group->Ava Scene 4B]]</li> <li>[[Organize a petition for recognition to present to the lab directors->Ava Scene 4F]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 3E --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Waiting for the Right Moment</h2> <p> You decide to keep your documentation hidden, storing your notes and photographs in a locked drawer. The world doesn’t seem ready to hear your story, and you worry that speaking out might bring unwanted consequences. </p> <p> Still, you take comfort in knowing that the truth is preserved, even if it remains in the shadows for now. You tell yourself that someday, when the time is right, your records will help set the story straight. </p> <p> As the years pass, you watch as the ENIAC becomes a legend, its true creators forgotten. But you hold onto hope that the evidence you’ve saved will one day help rewrite history. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women who contributed to early computing kept their records private for decades, fearing backlash or believing the world wasn’t ready to listen.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <p> <strong>What do you do?</strong> </p> <ul> <li>[[Eventually share your records with a new generation of historians->Ava Scene 4I]]</li> <li>[[Continue to keep your story hidden, focusing on your private pride->Ava Scene 4C]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 3D --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Reaching Out</h2> <p> You decide to share your documentation with a trusted journalist who has written about science and technology. You carefully package your notes, diagrams, and photographs, along with a letter explaining the true story behind ENIAC’s success. </p> <p> Weeks pass before you receive a reply. The journalist is fascinated and asks to meet in person. You feel a mix of excitement and anxiety—will your story finally be told, or will it be dismissed like so many times before? </p> <p> When you meet, the journalist listens intently, taking notes and asking thoughtful questions. For the first time, you sense that someone outside the lab truly understands what you and your colleagues accomplished. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> It was not until the 1980s and 1990s that journalists and historians began to uncover and publicize the stories of the ENIAC women, thanks in part to the documents and oral histories they preserved.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <p> <strong>What do you do?</strong> </p> <ul> <li>[[Agree to a public interview to share your story widely->Ava Scene 4G]]</li> <li>[[Ask the journalist to keep your identity private for now->Ava Scene 4H]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 4D --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>The Historian’s Visit</h2> <p> You reach out to a university historian known for researching wartime science. She visits your home, paging through your journal with growing excitement. She asks careful questions, recording your memories for posterity. </p> <p> As you talk, you realize how much you remember—the late-night breakthroughs, the camaraderie, the sting of being overlooked. The historian promises to share your story with her students and colleagues. </p> <p> For the first time, you feel the weight of history shifting. Perhaps, with the help of scholars, your story will finally be told. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Oral histories and interviews with surviving ENIAC women played a key role in rewriting computing history.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Allow the historian to publish your story in an academic journal->Ava Scene 5G]]</li> <li>[[Ask her to keep your identity anonymous for now->Ava Scene 5H]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 4E --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Hidden Pages</h2> <p> You tuck your journal away, deep in a drawer, uncertain if the world is ready for your truth. Each time you see it, you feel a pang of regret, but fear and doubt keep you silent. </p> <p> Years go by. The ENIAC is celebrated in books and documentaries, but the women behind its success are rarely mentioned. Sometimes you wonder if you should have spoken up, but the risks always seemed too high. </p> <p> One day, a young researcher contacts you, asking about your time at the lab. The decision to reveal your story, or to let it remain hidden, is yours once again. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women’s stories in tech were lost because they felt it was too risky to speak up, or believed no one would care.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Share your journal with the researcher->Ava Scene 5I]]</li> <li>[[Decline to share, letting your story remain private->Ava Scene 5J]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 4F --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>The Petition</h2> <p> With the group’s encouragement, you draft a petition demanding official recognition for the ENIAC women’s contributions. You gather signatures and present the document to the lab directors, hoping your collective voice will be heard. </p> <p> The directors are taken aback, unsure how to respond. Some are sympathetic, while others dismiss your concerns as “unprofessional.” The experience is nerve-wracking, but you feel empowered by your courage. </p> <p> The petition sparks quiet conversations in the lab. Some colleagues support your cause, while others keep their distance. Whether or not it succeeds, you know you’ve taken a stand for yourself and your peers. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Women in STEM have long used petitions and collective action to push for recognition and better working conditions, often facing resistance.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Wait to see if the directors respond favorably->Ava Scene 5K]]</li> <li>[[Take your petition public, contacting the press->Ava Scene 5L]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 4G --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Going Public</h2> <p> You agree to a public interview, sharing your story with the world. The journalist publishes an article highlighting your role and the contributions of other women programmers. </p> <p> The response is overwhelming. Former colleagues reach out, and students write to thank you for inspiring them. For the first time, you see your name in print, linked to the legacy you helped build. </p> <p> Recognition feels both exhilarating and strange. You wonder what new doors might open now that your story is finally out. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Public recognition of the ENIAC women began to grow in the 1990s and 2000s, inspiring new generations of women in computing.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Speak at a university event about your experiences->Ava Scene 5M]]</li> <li>[[Decline further publicity and enjoy your recognition quietly->Ava Scene 5N]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 4H --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Staying Anonymous</h2> <p> You ask the journalist to keep your identity private for now. The story is published as an anonymous account, sparking curiosity and debate in the computing community. </p> <p> Some readers speculate about the author’s identity, while others focus on the substance of your revelations. You watch from a distance, satisfied that the truth is finally being told, even if your name remains hidden. </p> <p> Over time, your story inspires others to come forward. The movement for recognition grows, built on the foundation you helped lay. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Anonymous testimonies and whistleblowers have played a key role in exposing hidden histories in science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Reveal your identity later, joining the public conversation->Ava Scene 5O]]</li> <li>[[Remain anonymous, content to see change from the shadows->Ava Scene 5P]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 4I --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Passing the Torch</h2> <p> Years later, you meet a young woman studying computer science who is fascinated by the history of ENIAC. She asks about your experiences, eager to learn from the past. </p> <p> You decide the time is right to share your hidden records. You pass on your notes, photographs, and stories, watching her eyes light up as she realizes the depth of your contributions. </p> <p> As she promises to share your story with her classmates, you feel a sense of peace. Even if you never receive public recognition, you’ve ensured that the truth will live on in the next generation. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many stories of women in computing were preserved thanks to intergenerational sharing and mentorship.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Encourage her to publish your story in a student journal->Ava Scene 5Q]]</li> <li>[[Ask her to keep your story within her community for now->Ava Scene 5R]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5C --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Publishing on Your Own Terms</h2> <p> You and your colleagues decide to self-publish your memoir, determined to keep your voices authentic and unfiltered. The process is daunting—editing, formatting, and distributing the book all fall on your shoulders. </p> <p> When the memoir is finally released, you send copies to libraries, universities, and former colleagues. The response is slow at first, but soon you receive letters from young women inspired by your story. </p> <p> Even if your book never makes the bestseller lists, you know you’ve created a record that will outlast you—a testament to the women who helped build the digital age. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many foundational memoirs and oral histories by women in STEM were self-published, bypassing traditional publishers who overlooked their stories.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Promote the memoir at local schools and community events->Ava Scene 6E]]</li> <li>[[Send the memoir to national science organizations->Ava Scene 6F]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5D --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Seeking a Wider Audience</h2> <p> You submit your manuscript to several major publishers. After weeks of waiting, one expresses interest—on the condition that they can edit the content for “clarity” and “market appeal.” You worry that your authentic voice may be lost in the process. </p> <p> The publisher’s editor suggests focusing more on the men’s achievements and less on the obstacles faced by the women. You and your co-authors debate whether to accept the changes or walk away. </p> <p> The decision weighs heavily: is it better to reach a wider audience with a diluted story, or to preserve your truth for a smaller group of readers? </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women in tech history found their stories altered or minimized by publishers seeking to fit mainstream narratives.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Accept the edits to reach more readers->Ava Scene 6G]]</li> <li>[[Withdraw the manuscript and consider self-publishing->Ava Scene 6H]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5E --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Reflecting on Legacy</h2> <p> After the celebration, you spend time reflecting on your journey. You revisit old notes, photographs, and mementos from your days at the lab. Each artifact is a reminder of the challenges you overcame and the friendships you forged. </p> <p> You consider sharing your story more widely, but for now, you find comfort in your private pride. The world may not know your name, but you know the truth of your own accomplishments. </p> <p> As you watch new generations of women enter the field, you hope that someday, the barriers you faced will be gone, and every contribution will be celebrated. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many pioneering women in science and technology left behind personal archives that later became invaluable for historians.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Reach out to a local university to donate your archives->Ava Scene 6I]]</li> <li>[[Encourage a young mentee to continue your legacy->Ava Scene 6J]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5F --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Moving Forward</h2> <p> You decide it’s time to focus on new challenges. You apply your skills to other projects, teaching, mentoring, or perhaps even starting a family. The ENIAC years become a cherished, if bittersweet, memory. </p> <p> Life moves on, and you find joy in new pursuits. Still, whenever you see a news story about computers or technology, you smile quietly, knowing you helped lay the foundation. </p> <p> You wonder if, someday, someone will discover the hidden stories of the women who built the digital world. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women who made foundational contributions to computing left the field for other careers or family, their stories rediscovered only decades later.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Write a memoir about your experiences later in life->Ava Scene 6K]]</li> <li>[[Let your story remain a private memory->Ava Scene 6L]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5G --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Academic Recognition</h2> <p> The historian is thrilled by your story and asks permission to publish your experiences in an academic journal. After some thought, you agree, hoping that your testimony will reach students, scholars, and future generations of computer scientists. </p> <p> When the article is published, it sparks conversations in university classrooms and conferences. Young women approach you at events, eager to hear more about your journey and the challenges you faced. </p> <p> For the first time, you feel a sense of validation—not just for yourself, but for all the women whose work was hidden for so long. Your story becomes part of the official record, inspiring others to look deeper into the untold history of technology. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> In recent decades, academic research and oral histories have played a crucial role in bringing the ENIAC women’s achievements into the spotlight, reshaping how computer science history is taught.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women";</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Participate in a university panel discussion->Ava Scene 6M]]</li> <li>[[Decline public appearances and focus on your personal projects->Ava Scene 6N]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5H --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Anonymous Testimony</h2> <p> You ask the historian to keep your identity confidential, at least for now. She publishes your story as an anonymous account, focusing on the technical details and the broader context of women’s contributions to ENIAC. </p> <p> The article generates buzz among historians and students. Some readers speculate about the author’s identity, while others are simply inspired by the story itself. </p> <p> You watch from a distance as your experiences spark new research and debate. Even without your name attached, your voice shapes the conversation about women in computing. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Anonymous and pseudonymous testimonies have often been used by women in STEM to share their stories safely, especially when facing discrimination or backlash.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Reveal your identity later as the author->Ava Scene 6O]]</li> <li>[[Remain anonymous and continue to support other women privately->Ava Scene 6P]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5I --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Sharing the Hidden Record</h2> <p> You decide to trust the young researcher and share your journal. She is amazed by the depth and detail of your notes, and promises to use them to set the record straight. </p> <p> The researcher incorporates your story into her thesis, which is later published and shared at conferences. For the first time, your name appears in academic footnotes and acknowledgments. </p> <p> You feel a sense of relief and pride, knowing that your experiences will inform and inspire future generations. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many graduate students and young scholars have played a key role in uncovering and publicizing the stories of women in computing, often using primary sources and oral histories.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Attend a conference to see your story presented->Ava Scene 6Q]]</li> <li>[[Encourage the researcher to continue her work and mentor others->Ava Scene 6R]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5J --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Letting the Past Rest</h2> <p> You politely decline the researcher's request, deciding that your story will remain a private memory. The journal stays tucked away, its pages yellowing with time. </p> <p> Occasionally, you reread your notes, reliving the triumphs and frustrations of your days at the lab. You wonder how history might have changed if you had chosen to share your experiences. </p> <p> In the end, you find peace in knowing that you made your choices for your own reasons. The world may never know your name, but you carry your story with quiet dignity. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women in early computing never received recognition for their work, and some chose to keep their stories private for personal reasons.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Reflect on your legacy as you grow older->Ava Scene 6S]]</li> <li>[[Consider donating your journal anonymously in the future->Ava Scene 6T]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5K --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Waiting for Change</h2> <p> After submitting your petition, you and your colleagues anxiously await a response from the lab directors. Weeks pass with little more than polite acknowledgments and vague promises of review. </p> <p> Eventually, a memo is circulated recognizing the “dedicated support staff” of the ENIAC project, but your names are not mentioned. The recognition feels hollow, but you sense that your efforts have planted a seed for future change. </p> <p> Though disappointed, you and your friends continue to support each other, determined that someday, the truth will come out. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Early attempts by women in computing to gain recognition were often met with vague or generic acknowledgments, but their persistence laid the groundwork for later breakthroughs.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Try again by contacting higher authorities->Ava Scene 6U]]</li> <li>[[Focus on mentoring the next generation of women in tech->Ava Scene 6V]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5L --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Taking the Story Public</h2> <p> Frustrated by the lack of official response, you decide to take your petition to the press. A local newspaper runs a story about the ENIAC women, highlighting your technical achievements and the ongoing struggle for recognition. </p> <p> The article sparks a flurry of interest. Other women in tech reach out to share their own stories, and soon a national conversation begins about the overlooked pioneers of computing. </p> <p> Though some colleagues are wary of the attention, you know you’ve helped open the door for a new era of recognition and respect. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Media coverage and public advocacy have been essential in gaining recognition for women’s contributions to science and technology, both historically and today.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Odetta Blog;</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Speak at a public event about your experiences->Ava Scene 6W]]</li> <li>[[Support other women coming forward with their stories->Ava Scene 6X]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5M --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Inspiring the Next Generation</h2> <p> You accept an invitation to speak at a university event. Standing before a packed auditorium, you share stories of late nights debugging ENIAC, the camaraderie among the women programmers, and the challenges of working in a male-dominated field. </p> <p> The students listen intently, many taking notes or recording your talk. Afterward, young women approach you to thank you for paving the way and to ask for advice on their own journeys in STEM. </p> <p> As you leave the campus, you feel a sense of fulfillment. Your story has become a beacon for others, proof that every voice matters in the history of technology. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Public talks and outreach by pioneering women in computing have inspired countless students and helped diversify the field.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org; Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Mentor a group of aspiring women programmers->Ava Scene 6Y]]</li> <li>[[Write a guidebook for future generations->Ava Scene 6Z]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5N --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Quiet Recognition</h2> <p> You choose to enjoy your newfound recognition quietly, declining further publicity. Friends, family, and former colleagues reach out to congratulate you, and you savor the private messages of gratitude from women inspired by your story. </p> <p> Life settles into a peaceful rhythm. You continue to follow advances in technology, feeling pride whenever you see women celebrated for their achievements in computing. </p> <p> Though your public role is brief, you know you have contributed to a larger movement. Sometimes, the most profound change comes from stories whispered between generations. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many pioneering women in computing preferred quiet recognition, finding fulfillment in knowing their story had made a difference.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org; Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Support other women’s stories behind the scenes->Ava Scene 6AA]]</li> <li>[[Write letters of encouragement to young women in STEM->Ava Scene 6AB]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5O --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Stepping Into the Light</h2> <p> After seeing the impact of your anonymous account, you decide to reveal your identity as the author. The news spreads quickly, and you are invited to speak at conferences and participate in interviews. </p> <p> Your courage encourages others to come forward with their stories. The computing community begins to recognize the breadth of women’s contributions, and your name becomes synonymous with resilience and innovation. </p> <p> You reflect on your journey, grateful that your voice has helped change the narrative for women in technology. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Some ENIAC women, like Jean Jennings Bartik, became public advocates for women in computing later in life, inspiring others by sharing their stories.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org; Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Establish a scholarship for women in STEM->Ava Scene 6AC]]</li> <li>[[Write a memoir to preserve your legacy->Ava Scene 6AD]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5P --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Guiding from the Shadows</h2> <p> You choose to remain anonymous, quietly supporting other women who wish to share their stories. You offer advice, encouragement, and sometimes even your own research and notes to help others find their voice. </p> <p> Watching the movement grow, you feel a sense of accomplishment. Even without public recognition, you know you have played a vital role in changing the narrative. </p> <p> Sometimes, true leadership is about empowering others to shine. You are content knowing your influence will ripple through generations. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women in STEM have chosen to mentor and support others from behind the scenes, shaping the field through quiet leadership.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Encourage a new generation of advocates->Ava Scene 6AE]]</li> <li>[[Continue to collect and preserve women’s stories->Ava Scene 6AF]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5Q --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Student Voices</h2> <p> You encourage the young woman to publish your story in her university’s student journal. The article quickly becomes popular, sparking campus discussions about women’s roles in technology and the importance of preserving hidden histories. </p> <p> Other students reach out to you, eager to learn more. You participate in virtual Q&A sessions, sharing your insights and advice with a new generation. </p> <p> Your story, once hidden, now inspires students across disciplines. You realize that even small publications can have a big impact. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Student-led publications and grassroots projects have often been at the forefront of surfacing marginalized voices in science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Speak at a student-organized tech symposium->Ava Scene 6AG]]</li> <li>[[Encourage students to research other hidden figures in computing->Ava Scene 6AH]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 5R --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Community Legacy</h2> <p> You ask the young woman to keep your story within her community for now, trusting her to share it with care. She organizes small gatherings where she reads your account and leads discussions about women in technology. </p> <p> The story spreads quietly, inspiring others to look into their own family histories and local archives. You hear about new projects and exhibits popping up in libraries and community centers. </p> <p> Sometimes, the most lasting change begins in small circles. You take comfort in knowing your legacy is growing, one conversation at a time. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Community storytelling and local history projects have been vital in preserving the stories of women and other marginalized groups in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Visit a local exhibit featuring your story->Ava Scene 6AI]]</li> <li>[[Help organize an oral history project in your town->Ava Scene 6AJ]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6A --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Headline News</h2> <p> The day the article is published, you rush to buy a copy of the newspaper. There, in bold print, is a story about the ENIAC women—your story. The journalist describes your technical achievements and the injustice of your erasure from history. </p> <p> Letters and phone calls begin to arrive. Some are from former colleagues who remember your work; others are from young women inspired to pursue careers in science and technology. The recognition is overwhelming, but also deeply gratifying. </p> <p> For the first time, you feel seen—not just as a support worker, but as a pioneer. Your story is now part of the public record, and you wonder what new opportunities might follow. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Public media coverage has played a crucial role in restoring the names and stories of women like the ENIAC programmers to the historical record.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Accept an invitation to speak at a local school->Ava Scene 7A]]</li> <li>[[Write a follow-up letter to the editor, thanking the journalist->Ava Scene 7B]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6B --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Building a Movement</h2> <p> With your encouragement, more ENIAC women come forward, sharing their stories with the journalist. The resulting series of articles becomes a sensation, sparking national conversations about women in STEM. </p> <p> You help organize a reunion, bringing together women who haven’t seen each other in decades. The event is filled with laughter, tears, and a sense of vindication. </p> <p> As the movement grows, you realize that your courage has helped change not just your own legacy, but the legacy of an entire generation. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Group interviews and reunions of ENIAC women in the 1980s and 1990s were pivotal in rewriting computing history.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help organize a documentary about the ENIAC women->Ava Scene 7C]]</li> <li>[[Support a campaign for a national memorial->Ava Scene 7D]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6C --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>On the Panel</h2> <p> You and your colleagues are invited to speak at a public panel about the history of computing. The auditorium is packed with students, journalists, and even a few former skeptics. </p> <p> Each woman shares her story, and together you paint a vivid picture of the teamwork, creativity, and perseverance that powered ENIAC. The audience is moved, and many express shock at how long these stories were hidden. </p> <p> After the event, you receive invitations to speak at other institutions, and your story is cited in textbooks and documentaries. You feel a sense of justice—at last, the world is listening. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Public panels and conferences have been crucial for surfacing hidden histories and inspiring new research.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Travel to other cities to share your story->Ava Scene 7E]]</li> <li>[[Mentor young women interested in computing->Ava Scene 7F]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6D --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Returning to Quiet Life</h2> <p> After the flurry of media attention, you choose to step back and let the journalist handle the story. Life returns to its familiar rhythms, but you notice small signs of change: a mention in a textbook, a thank-you note from a student, a new exhibit at a local museum. </p> <p> You feel content knowing you played a part in bringing the truth to light, even if you prefer to remain out of the spotlight yourself. </p> <p> Sometimes, progress is slow and subtle, but you know that every story shared is a step toward justice. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women in STEM have chosen to let others tell their stories, finding fulfillment in seeing the next generation benefit from their efforts.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Support a local science education program->Ava Scene 7G]]</li> <li>[[Write letters to encourage other women to share their stories->Ava Scene 7H]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6E --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Grassroots Impact</h2> <p> You promote your self-published memoir at local schools and community events. Students and teachers are fascinated by your firsthand account, and you’re invited to speak at assemblies and science fairs. </p> <p> Your story spreads by word of mouth, inspiring a new generation of girls to pursue careers in technology. You see your influence ripple through your community, planting seeds for the future. </p> <p> You realize that sometimes, the most meaningful change starts close to home. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Local outreach and community engagement have been crucial for encouraging girls and women to pursue STEM fields.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Develop a STEM club for girls at a local school->Ava Scene 7I]]</li> <li>[[Submit your story to a national women’s history project->Ava Scene 7J]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6F --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>National Recognition</h2> <p> You send your memoir to national science organizations and women’s advocacy groups. Soon, excerpts appear in newsletters, websites, and even in a documentary about women in technology. </p> <p> Your story reaches a much wider audience than you ever imagined. You receive invitations to participate in national panels and your book is cited in academic research. </p> <p> You feel proud knowing your voice has helped shape the national conversation about women in computing. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> National science organizations have increasingly recognized the contributions of women pioneers in technology, often thanks to grassroots advocacy.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org; Jennifer S.
