Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Travel to a national conference to share your story->Ava Scene 7K]]</li> <li>[[Nominate your colleagues for national honors->Ava Scene 7L]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6G --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Compromise for Reach</h2> <p> You and your co-authors reluctantly accept the publisher’s edits, hoping that reaching a broader audience will outweigh the loss of some authenticity. The book is released to positive reviews, though you notice that some of the more challenging stories have been softened or omitted. </p> <p> Despite these changes, your story sparks conversation and inspires readers across the country. You receive letters from women who see themselves in your journey, and from men who express surprise at the obstacles you overcame. </p> <p> You reflect on the trade-off, recognizing that sometimes, progress requires difficult choices. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women in tech history had to compromise to get their stories published, but even edited accounts helped change public perceptions.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Speak at a book launch event->Ava Scene 7M]]</li> <li>[[Privately record the unedited stories for posterity->Ava Scene 7N]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6H --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Preserving Your Truth</h2> <p> Unwilling to let your story be diluted, you withdraw the manuscript and return to the idea of self-publishing. You and your co-authors work late into the night, determined to preserve every detail, even if your audience is smaller. </p> <p> When the memoir is released, it resonates deeply with those who read it. Scholars and activists cite your work, and you become a source of inspiration for women who want to share their own unfiltered stories. </p> <p> You realize that sometimes, authenticity matters more than reach. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Self-published memoirs and oral histories have become invaluable resources for historians studying women in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Organize a reading at a local library->Ava Scene 7O]]</li> <li>[[Submit your memoir to a women’s history archive->Ava Scene 7P]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6I --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Donating Your Archives</h2> <p> You reach out to a local university and offer to donate your notes, photographs, and memorabilia. The archivist is thrilled, recognizing the historical value of your collection. </p> <p> Your materials are catalogued and made available to researchers and students. You are invited to campus to speak about your experiences and to see your contributions preserved for future generations. </p> <p> You take pride in knowing your legacy will endure, helping others understand the true story of the ENIAC women. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> University archives and museums have become important repositories for the personal papers and artifacts of women in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Give a guest lecture at the university->Ava Scene 7Q]]</li> <li>[[Mentor students interested in archival research->Ava Scene 7R]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6J --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Mentoring the Future</h2> <p> You decide to mentor a young woman interested in computer science. Over coffee and long walks, you share stories, advice, and encouragement, helping her navigate the challenges of the field. </p> <p> Watching her grow and succeed, you feel a sense of pride. She credits you as her inspiration, and you realize that your legacy lives on through her achievements. </p> <p> Sometimes, the most lasting impact comes not from public recognition, but from the lives you touch directly. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Mentorship has been shown to be one of the most effective ways to support women and underrepresented groups in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Encourage your mentee to document her own journey->Ava Scene 7S]]</li> <li>[[Help her start a support network for women in tech->Ava Scene 7T]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6K --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Writing Your Memoir</h2> <p> Years after leaving the lab, you decide to write a memoir about your experiences as an ENIAC programmer. The process is emotional, bringing back memories of both triumph and frustration. </p> <p> As you write, you realize how far you—and the world—have come. You include stories of your colleagues, the technical breakthroughs, and the quiet determination that defined your work. </p> <p> When the book is finished, you share it with friends, family, and a few historians. Your story, once hidden, is now a testament to the women who helped launch the digital age. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Memoirs and autobiographies by women in computing have become important historical documents for researchers and students.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Donate your memoir to a library or archive->Ava Scene 7U]]</li> <li>[[Publish excerpts online for a wider audience->Ava Scene 7V]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6L --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Private Memory</h2> <p> You choose to let your story remain a private memory, shared only with close friends and family. Sometimes, in quiet moments, you reread your old notes and relive the days spent in the ENIAC lab. The pride you feel is real, even if it’s never recognized in public. </p> <p> Over the years, you watch as the world’s understanding of computing evolves. Occasionally, you see a documentary or read an article about ENIAC, and you smile quietly, knowing you played a role in something monumental. </p> <p> As you grow older, you consider whether to finally share your story, but you are at peace with your decision. The legacy of ENIAC lives on, and so does your quiet contribution. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many ENIAC programmers’ stories remained private for decades, only surfacing when family members or historians discovered their notes or heard their stories late in life.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Odetta Blog; IEEE Computer Society</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Donate your notes anonymously to a museum or archive->Ava Scene 7W]]</li> <li>[[Share your story with a grandchild who is curious about your past->Ava Scene 7X]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6M --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Panel Discussion</h2> <p> You accept an invitation to participate in a university panel discussion about the history of computing. Sitting alongside other pioneers, you share your experiences and answer questions from eager students. </p> <p> The audience is captivated by your stories of problem-solving, teamwork, and the challenges of working on a secret project during wartime. You emphasize how much of the ENIAC’s success depended on women’s ingenuity and perseverance. </p> <p> After the event, several students approach you, inspired to pursue careers in technology. You realize your story is helping shape the next generation of innovators. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many ENIAC women became advocates and educators later in life, using their stories to inspire and mentor young people.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: IEEE Computer Society; SWE Magazine</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Mentor a student interested in computer science->Ava Scene 7Y]]</li> <li>[[Write an article about your experiences for a university magazine->Ava Scene 7Z]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6N --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Personal Projects</h2> <p> You decide to decline further public appearances, focusing instead on personal projects. You volunteer at a local library, help organize community science fairs, and spend time with your family. </p> <p> Though you’re no longer in the spotlight, you find fulfillment in small acts of mentorship and support. You encourage young people to explore math and science, sometimes slipping them stories from your past. </p> <p> You realize that not all legacies are public—some are felt in the quiet encouragement that helps others grow. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many ENIAC women continued to contribute to their communities in education and outreach, even after leaving the field.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Odetta Blog; IEEE Computer Society</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Start a math club at the library->Ava Scene 7AA]]</li> <li>[[Write a children’s book about early computers->Ava Scene 7AB]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6O --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Claiming Your Story</h2> <p> After seeing the impact of your anonymous testimony, you decide to reveal your identity. The academic and tech communities are abuzz, and you’re invited to speak at conferences and contribute to new research projects. </p> <p> Your courage encourages others to come forward with their stories, and the movement for recognition grows. You become a role model for women in technology, your name finally linked to the legacy you helped build. </p> <p> Looking back, you feel grateful for the chance to help rewrite history—not just for yourself, but for everyone whose story was nearly lost. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Some ENIAC women, like Jean Jennings Bartik, became public advocates for women in computing later in life, inspiring others by sharing their stories.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org; IEEE Computer Society</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Establish a scholarship for women in STEM->Ava Scene 7AC]]</li> <li>[[Write a memoir to preserve your legacy->Ava Scene 7AD]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6P --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Supporting from the Shadows</h2> <p> You decide to remain anonymous, quietly supporting other women who wish to share their stories. You offer advice, encouragement, and sometimes even your own research and notes to help others find their voice. </p> <p> Watching the movement grow, you feel a sense of accomplishment. Even without public recognition, you know you have played a vital role in changing the narrative. </p> <p> Sometimes, true leadership is about empowering others to shine. You are content knowing your influence will ripple through generations. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women in STEM have chosen to mentor and support others from behind the scenes, shaping the field through quiet leadership.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Encourage a new generation of advocates->Ava Scene 7AE]]</li> <li>[[Continue to collect and preserve women’s stories->Ava Scene 7AF]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6Q --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Conference Spotlight</h2> <p> You attend a conference where the young researcher presents your story. As you listen from the audience, you’re struck by the impact your experiences have on the attendees. </p> <p> After the presentation, students and scholars approach you with questions and gratitude. Many express surprise at how much of computing’s history was hidden for so long. </p> <p> You feel a sense of pride and closure, knowing your story is now part of the larger narrative. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Conferences and academic presentations have helped bring the ENIAC women’s contributions into mainstream historical accounts.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: IEEE Computer Society; SWE Magazine</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Join a panel to discuss the future of women in tech->Ava Scene 7AG]]</li> <li>[[Encourage others to share their hidden histories->Ava Scene 7AH]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6R --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Mentoring a Historian</h2> <p> You encourage the young researcher to continue her work and mentor others interested in women’s history in STEM. Together, you help organize workshops and seminars, sharing your story and teaching research skills. </p> <p> You watch with pride as a new generation of historians and technologists emerges, determined to uncover and celebrate hidden stories. </p> <p> Your legacy is now part of a growing movement to ensure that no one’s contributions are forgotten. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Mentorship and collaboration between generations have been key to preserving and expanding the history of women in computing.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: SWE Magazine; Odetta Blog</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help organize a national oral history project->Ava Scene 7AI]]</li> <li>[[Support a new documentary about women in computing->Ava Scene 7AJ]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6S --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Reflections in Later Life</h2> <p> As the years pass, you reflect on your journey and the choices you made. You find comfort in the knowledge that you were part of something groundbreaking, even if your name never made it into the headlines. </p> <p> Sometimes, you share a story or two with family or friends, but mostly you keep your memories close. You watch as new generations of women enter the field, hoping their paths will be easier. </p> <p> You realize that every act of perseverance, no matter how quiet, helped lay the foundation for the digital world. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Many women who worked on ENIAC lived to see their field transformed, and some were honored late in life for their pioneering work.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Odetta Blog; IEEE Computer Society</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Record an oral history for your family->Ava Scene 7AK]]</li> <li>[[Leave your notes to a university archive in your will->Ava Scene 7AL]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6T --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>An Anonymous Gift</h2> <p> You decide to donate your journal and notes anonymously to a university archive. The archivists are thrilled to receive such a detailed account of early computing, even if the author’s identity remains a mystery. </p> <p> Years later, researchers and students pore over your records, piecing together the story of the ENIAC women. Your words help fill gaps in the historical record, even as your name remains unknown. </p> <p> You find satisfaction in knowing your story will help others, whether or not you receive credit. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Anonymous archival donations have helped historians uncover hidden stories in science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: IEEE Computer Society; Odetta Blog</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Reveal your identity in a letter to the archive later->Ava Scene 7AM]]</li> <li>[[Let the story stand on its own, author unknown->Ava Scene 7AN]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6U --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Appealing to Higher Authorities</h2> <p> Frustrated by the lack of meaningful recognition, you and your colleagues decide to take your petition to higher authorities—perhaps a national science foundation or a prominent women’s organization. </p> <p> The process is slow and bureaucratic, but eventually your efforts attract attention. A national committee is formed to review the history of women in computing, and your story is included in their report. </p> <p> The recognition is not immediate, but you sense that progress is being made, one step at a time. Your persistence helps pave the way for future generations to receive the credit they deserve. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> National advocacy campaigns and appeals to scientific organizations have been crucial in achieving official recognition for women’s contributions to computing.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: SWE Magazine; IEEE Computer Society</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help organize a national celebration of women in tech->Ava Scene 7AO]]</li> <li>[[Mentor young advocates to continue the work->Ava Scene 7AP]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6V --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Publishing Online</h2> <p> You decide to publish excerpts from your memoir online, making your story accessible to anyone with an internet connection. The response is immediate—comments and emails pour in from readers around the world who are moved by your journey. </p> <p> Your story is shared on social media, discussed in forums, and cited in blog posts about women in technology. You’re invited to participate in virtual panels and podcasts, reaching audiences you never imagined. </p> <p> The digital world amplifies your voice, ensuring that the story of the ENIAC women is no longer hidden, but celebrated everywhere. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> The internet has become a powerful tool for sharing and preserving the stories of women and other marginalized groups in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"; eniacprogrammers.org</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Host an online Q&A about your experiences->Ava Scene 7AQ]]</li> <li>[[Collaborate with digital historians to create an online archive->Ava Scene 7AR]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6W --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Speaking Out</h2> <p> You accept an invitation to speak at a public event about your experiences as an ENIAC programmer. Standing before a crowd, you share the challenges, triumphs, and lessons learned from your pioneering work. </p> <p> The audience is captivated, and many approach you afterward to express their gratitude and admiration. Your voice inspires others to reflect on the hidden figures in their own fields. </p> <p> You realize that sharing your story has not only honored the past but also encouraged others to seek out and celebrate untold histories. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Public speaking and storytelling have been essential for raising awareness about women’s contributions to science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org; IEEE Computer Society</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Organize a series of talks at local schools->Ava Scene 7AS]]</li> <li>[[Record your talk for an educational video series->Ava Scene 7AT]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6X --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Supporting New Voices</h2> <p> You dedicate yourself to supporting other women coming forward with their stories. You help organize workshops, review manuscripts, and connect storytellers with journalists and historians. </p> <p> Your efforts create a ripple effect, as more and more women in STEM find the courage to share their experiences. The movement grows, and public understanding of computing history deepens. </p> <p> You find deep fulfillment in helping others step into the spotlight, knowing that every story told brings the world closer to truth and equality. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Networks of support and mentorship have been vital for empowering women to share their stories and advocate for change.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"; Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help launch a national campaign for women in STEM->Ava Scene 7AU]]</li> <li>[[Mentor a new generation of storytellers->Ava Scene 7AV]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6Y --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Mentoring the Next Generation</h2> <p> You take a group of aspiring women programmers under your wing, meeting regularly to discuss coding, career challenges, and the history of women in tech. The book blends technical advice, personal stories, and encouragement for young women entering STEM. </p> <p> When it’s published, the guidebook is adopted by schools and mentorship programs. Some recipients write back, grateful for the support and inspiration. </p> <p> Over time, your letters are shared among students and professionals, forming a network of encouragement that spans generations. </p> <p> You realize that small acts of kindness can have a profound ripple effect, helping to build a more inclusive and supportive community. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Personal letters and mentorship have historically played a crucial role in supporting women and minorities in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Compile your letters into a published collection->Ava Scene 7AE]]</li> <li>[[Encourage your mentees to write their own letters->Ava Scene 7AF]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6AC --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Establishing a Scholarship</h2> <p> You work with a local university to establish a scholarship for women in STEM, using your story to inspire donors and applicants alike. The first recipients write to thank you, sharing their dreams and ambitions. </p> <p> As the scholarship grows, you see its impact ripple outward—more women enrolling in computer science, more voices joining the conversation. </p> <p> You feel immense pride, knowing your legacy will help open doors for generations to come. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Scholarships and financial support have been shown to significantly increase diversity and retention in STEM fields.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Mentor scholarship recipients->Ava Scene 7AG]]</li> <li>[[Encourage recipients to give back as mentors->Ava Scene 7AH]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6AD --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Memoir for the Ages</h2> <p> You dedicate yourself to writing a memoir, weaving together your personal journey with the broader history of the ENIAC women. The process is cathartic, and you find joy in sharing both triumphs and struggles. </p> <p> When your memoir is published, it receives praise from historians, educators, and readers of all ages. You are invited to speak at conferences and contribute to documentaries about the history of computing. </p> <p> You take pride in knowing that your efforts will help future generations understand the true diversity of innovation. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Archives and oral history projects have been crucial for preserving the contributions of women and minorities in science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Their work helps expand the narrative of computing history. </p> <p> You are proud to have sparked a wave of curiosity and discovery, ensuring that more voices are heard and celebrated. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Student research projects have uncovered many previously unknown stories of women and minorities in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help students present their research at a national conference->Ava Scene 7AQ]]</li> <li>[[Support students in creating a digital archive->Ava Scene 7AR]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6AI --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Community Exhibit</h2> <p> You visit a local library where a new exhibit features your story alongside other trailblazing women in technology. Photographs, handwritten notes, and artifacts from your days at the ENIAC lab are displayed with care. Community members, students, and families wander through, pausing to read about your contributions. </p> <p> As you walk through the exhibit, you overhear a young girl telling her mother, “I want to be like her someday.” The moment fills you with pride and gratitude. Your once-hidden story is now inspiring others in your own hometown. </p> <p> The exhibit becomes a gathering place for discussions about history, technology, and the importance of recognizing everyone’s contributions. You realize that your legacy is alive and growing, rooted in the community that shaped you. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Local exhibits and museum displays have played a crucial role in preserving and sharing the stories of women in computing and STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"; eniacprogrammers.org</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Give a talk at the exhibit’s opening night->Ava Scene 7AO]]</li> <li>[[Donate more artifacts to expand the collection->Ava Scene 7AP]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 6AJ --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Oral History Project</h2> <p> You help organize an oral history project in your town, inviting women from all backgrounds to share their experiences in science, technology, and beyond. Over weeks, you record stories of perseverance, invention, and quiet heroism that might otherwise be forgotten. </p> <p> The project brings together students, elders, and community leaders, fostering connections across generations. As you listen to others, you realize how many untold stories still wait to be discovered. </p> <p> The collected interviews are archived at the local library and made available online, ensuring that the voices of your community will be heard for years to come. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Oral history projects have been vital for preserving the stories of women and minorities in STEM, especially at the local level.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"; SWE Magazine</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Present the project at a regional conference->Ava Scene 7AQ]]</li> <li>[[Encourage local schools to add these stories to their curriculum->Ava Scene 7AR]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7A --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Inspiring Young Minds</h2> <p> You accept an invitation to speak at a local school. The classroom is filled with curious faces, and as you share your story, you see excitement and wonder in their eyes. You talk about the challenges and triumphs of programming ENIAC, and the importance of perseverance and teamwork. </p> <p> After your talk, students gather around to ask questions. Some want to know more about computers, others about your experiences as a woman in science. You realize your story has sparked new dreams and ambitions. </p> <p> On your way home, you reflect on the power of storytelling. By sharing your journey, you’ve planted seeds for the next generation of innovators. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> School outreach and role models are key factors in encouraging girls to pursue STEM careers.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Organize a regular mentorship program at the school->Ava Scene 8A]]</li> <li>[[Encourage students to research hidden figures in science->Ava Scene 8B]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7B --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Gratitude and Connection</h2> <p> You write a heartfelt letter to the editor, thanking the journalist for shining a light on the ENIAC women. Your letter is published, and soon you receive messages from readers who were moved by your story. </p> <p> Some are former colleagues, others are strangers who feel inspired to share their own stories. You realize that gratitude can be a powerful force for connection and change. </p> <p> As your network grows, you find yourself at the center of a new community—one dedicated to honoring the hidden figures of science and technology. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Letters to the editor and public acknowledgments have helped build communities and networks among women in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Organize a local event to celebrate women in computing->Ava Scene 8C]]</li> <li>[[Start a newsletter for women in STEM->Ava Scene 8D]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7C --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Documenting History</h2> <p> You help organize a documentary about the ENIAC women. The process is both exciting and emotional—old friends are reunited, and long-forgotten stories are brought to life on camera. </p> <p> The film premieres to acclaim, sparking renewed interest in the history of women in computing. Schools and universities begin to incorporate your story into their curricula. </p> <p> You watch the credits roll with tears in your eyes, knowing you’ve helped ensure that the truth will not be forgotten. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Documentaries and films have played a major role in making the stories of women in STEM accessible to the public.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org; Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Travel to film screenings and Q&A sessions->Ava Scene 8E]]</li> <li>[[Help create educational materials to accompany the film->Ava Scene 8F]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7D --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>National Memorial</h2> <p> You support a campaign for a national memorial honoring the ENIAC women. The effort gains momentum, attracting support from advocacy groups, educators, and lawmakers. </p> <p> After years of advocacy, a commemorative plaque is installed at the site of the original ENIAC lab. The dedication ceremony is attended by former colleagues, family members, and young women inspired by your story. </p> <p> Standing before the memorial, you feel a sense of closure and pride. The world finally recognizes the pioneers who helped launch the digital age. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> National memorials and commemorative events have been crucial in acknowledging the achievements of women previously erased from STEM history.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Speak at the dedication ceremony->Ava Scene 8G]]</li> <li>[[Help organize annual events to honor women in computing->Ava Scene 8H]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7E --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>On the Road</h2> <p> You travel to other cities, sharing your story at universities, museums, and conferences. Each stop brings new faces and new opportunities to inspire. </p> <p> Along the way, you meet other women who have faced similar challenges. You exchange stories and advice, building a network of support that spans the country. </p> <p> The journey is exhausting but rewarding. You see firsthand how your story is helping to change perceptions and open doors for others. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Traveling speakers and advocates have played a key role in raising awareness and building networks for women in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: eniacprogrammers.org; Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Start a national mentorship initiative->Ava Scene 8I]]</li> <li>[[Write a travelogue about your experiences->Ava Scene 8J]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7F --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Mentoring the Future</h2> <p> Inspired by the panel’s success, you begin mentoring young women interested in computing. They credit your wisdom and support for helping them navigate a challenging field. </p> <p> You realize that your greatest legacy may be the lives you’ve touched and the doors you’ve helped open. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Mentorship is one of the most effective ways to support women and underrepresented groups in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"; eniacprogrammers.org</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help your mentees start their own mentorship circles->Ava Scene 8K]]</li> <li>[[Nominate your mentees for a national award->Ava Scene 8L]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7G --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Supporting Science Education</h2> <p> You decide to support a local science education program, volunteering your time to help design hands-on activities and mentor students. Your experience with ENIAC becomes a source of inspiration for the curriculum. </p> <p> Students are fascinated by your stories of early computing, and teachers appreciate your ability to make complex topics accessible. You see the impact of your efforts as more girls sign up for science and math clubs. </p> <p> You realize that inspiring curiosity and confidence in young minds is one of the most meaningful ways to honor your legacy. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Outreach and engagement by STEM professionals have been shown to increase student interest and participation in science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Others share their own journeys, creating a web of support and solidarity. </p> <p> You realize that even small acts of kindness can have a profound impact, helping to build a more inclusive and supportive community. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Personal correspondence and mentorship have historically played a crucial role in supporting women and minorities in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Compile the letters into a published collection->Ava Scene 8O]]</li> <li>[[Start an online letter-writing campaign for STEM students->Ava Scene 8P]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7I --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>STEM Club Pioneer</h2> <p> You help develop a STEM club for girls at a local school, designing activities that blend creativity, teamwork, and technical skills. Some go on to compete in science fairs, others start their own coding projects, and all of them credit the club for sparking their interest. </p> <p> You feel immense pride, knowing you’ve helped create a space where girls can explore and excel in STEM. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> After-school clubs and informal STEM programs have been shown to increase girls’ participation and retention in science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Donate copies of your book to libraries->Ava Scene 8Y]]</li> <li>[[Record an audiobook version for wider access->Ava Scene 8Z]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7N --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Private Recordings</h2> <p> You privately record the unedited stories of the ENIAC women, preserving the full truth for future generations. The recordings are stored in a safe place, with instructions to release them after your passing. </p> <p> You feel relief knowing that, one day, the world will hear the complete story, unfiltered and honest. </p> <p> Sometimes, the most important work is done quietly, with faith in the future. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Oral histories and private recordings have become invaluable resources for researchers studying women in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: SWE Magazine; IEEE Computer Society</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Donate the recordings to a university archive->Ava Scene 8AA]]</li> <li>[[Share the recordings with family and friends->Ava Scene 8AB]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7O --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Library Reading</h2> <p> You organize a reading of your memoir at the local library. The room fills with students, teachers, and neighbors, all eager to hear your story in your own words. As you read passages about late nights at the ENIAC lab and the camaraderie among the women programmers, you see nods of recognition and admiration. </p> <p> Afterward, attendees ask questions and share their own family stories of hidden achievements. The event sparks a lively discussion about the importance of preserving and sharing women’s histories. </p> <p> You leave the library with a sense of fulfillment, knowing you’ve inspired others to value and seek out the untold stories in their own communities. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Community readings and local events have played a crucial role in bringing women’s STEM stories to broader audiences.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Donate a copy of your memoir to the library->Ava Scene 8AC]]</li> <li>[[Encourage others to organize their own readings->Ava Scene 8AD]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7P --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Archiving for History</h2> <p> You submit your memoir to a women’s history archive, where it is catalogued alongside the stories of other pioneers. Researchers and students access your work, using it to inform their projects and papers. </p> <p> Occasionally, you receive letters from readers who found inspiration in your story. You are pleased to know that your experiences are helping to shape the historical record. </p> <p> Your memoir becomes a bridge between generations, ensuring that the lessons of the past are never forgotten. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Archives and special collections have become key resources for preserving and sharing women’s STEM histories.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Participate in a panel discussion for the archive->Ava Scene 8AE]]</li> <li>[[Support a digital archive project for women in tech->Ava Scene 8AF]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7Q --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Guest Lecture</h2> <p> You are invited to give a guest lecture at the university where your archives are housed. Standing before a packed auditorium, you share your journey from the ENIAC lab to the present day. </p> <p> Students and faculty listen intently, asking thoughtful questions about both the technical and personal aspects of your story. You encourage them to pursue their passions and to seek out the hidden histories in their own fields. </p> <p> Afterward, you are approached by students who thank you for paving the way. You leave campus knowing your legacy will continue to inspire. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Guest lectures and university visits by STEM pioneers have been shown to increase student engagement and interest in science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: IEEE Computer Society; eniacprogrammers.org</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help develop a course on the history of computing->Ava Scene 8AG]]</li> <li>[[Mentor a student research group->Ava Scene 8AH]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7R --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Mentoring Researchers</h2> <p> You take on the role of mentor to a group of students interested in archival research. Together, you explore the university’s collections, learning how to preserve and interpret historical documents. </p> <p> The students are inspired by your passion and expertise, and some decide to pursue careers in history or library science. You see your influence multiply as your mentees go on to mentor others. </p> <p> You understand that preserving the past is a collaborative effort, and you are proud to be part of a chain of knowledge keepers. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Mentorship in archival research helps ensure that important stories and documents are preserved and made accessible for future generations.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: SWE Magazine; Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Support a student-led exhibit on women in STEM->Ava Scene 8AI]]</li> <li>[[Write an article about the importance of archives->Ava Scene 8AJ]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7S --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Documenting New Journeys</h2> <p> You encourage your mentee to document her own journey in STEM, just as you did. She starts a blog, sharing her experiences, challenges, and victories with a growing audience. </p> <p> Her writing inspires other young women to share their stories, creating a vibrant online community of support and encouragement. </p> <p> You feel a sense of pride and continuity, knowing that your legacy lives on through the voices of the next generation. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Personal blogs and digital storytelling have become powerful tools for women in STEM to connect, advocate, and inspire.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help your mentee organize a digital storytelling workshop->Ava Scene 8AK]]</li> <li>[[Collaborate on a book of essays by women in STEM->Ava Scene 8AL]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7T --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Building a Support Network</h2> <p> You help your mentee start a support network for women in tech at her university. The group meets regularly to share experiences, offer advice, and organize events that highlight women’s achievements in computing. </p> <p> The network quickly grows, attracting members from across campus and beyond. You are invited to speak at their meetings, and your story becomes a touchstone for the group’s mission. </p> <p> You realize that community and solidarity are powerful tools for change, and you are proud to have helped build a foundation for others to thrive. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Support networks and affinity groups are proven to increase retention and success for women and minorities in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Mar Hicks, "Programmed Inequality"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Help the network organize a campus-wide tech conference->Ava Scene 8AM]]</li> <li>[[Encourage the group to partner with national organizations->Ava Scene 8AN]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7U --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Library Legacy</h2> <p> You donate your memoir to a local library or archive, ensuring that your story will be available to researchers, students, and curious readers for years to come. The librarian thanks you for your contribution, promising to highlight your work in upcoming exhibits and reading lists. </p> <p> Occasionally, you hear from readers who discovered your memoir by chance. Their messages remind you that even a single story can change someone’s perspective. </p> <p> You feel a sense of peace, knowing your experiences will continue to inspire and educate long after you are gone. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Donating personal papers and memoirs to libraries and archives is one of the most effective ways to preserve history for future generations.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Light, "When Computers Were Women"</span> </div> <ul> <li>[[Host a reading at the library to celebrate your donation->Ava Scene 8AO]]</li> <li>[[Encourage others to donate their stories as well->Ava Scene 8AP]]</li> </ul> </div> <!-- Title: Ava Scene 7V --> <style> .story-scene { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.45); padding: 32px; border-radius: 15px; max-width: 650px; margin: 40px auto 0 auto; color: #e0e0e0; box-shadow: 0 0 12px rgba(0,0,0,0.3); } .story-scene h2 { color: #b3e0ff; margin-bottom: 18px; font-size: 26px; } .story-scene p { margin-bottom: 10px; line-height: 1.6; font-size: 18px; } .fact-box { background: rgba(0,212,255,0.13); border-left: 4px solid #00d2ff; color: #b3e0ff; padding: 10px 20px; margin: 18px 0; font-size: 16px; border-radius: 8px; } </style> <div class="story-scene"> <h2>Digital Outreach</h2> <p> You publish excerpts of your memoir online, making your story accessible to a global audience. Readers from around the world comment on your posts, sharing their own experiences and expressing gratitude for your honesty. </p> <p> Your story is shared widely on social media, and you are invited to participate in virtual panels and podcasts. Speeches celebrate the groundbreaking work and the long-overdue recognition. </p> <p> The ceremony is emotional, filled with laughter, tears, and applause. You feel a deep sense of justice and closure, knowing that your contributions will be remembered for generations. </p> <p> As cameras flash and voices echo, you realize the power of persistence and solidarity in rewriting history. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Commemorative events and memorials have played a vital role in acknowledging women’s contributions to science and technology.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S. Their eyes widen with wonder as they hear about the machine that helped win a war and changed the world. </p> <p> Your family begins to cherish your history, preserving your journals and photographs as treasured heirlooms. Your story becomes a source of pride and inspiration for generations to come. </p> <p> You realize that legacies are not just public—they live in the hearts and minds of those we love. </p> <div class="fact-box"> <strong>Did you know?</strong> Family stories and personal archives have been crucial in preserving the histories of women in STEM.<br> <span style="font-style: italic;">Source: Jennifer S.
